text: I'm in Douma the town just on the edge
of Damascus which saw so much shelling
and destruction in the early part of
this year there was always a question
here about how the rebels sustained
themselves during so many years of siege
well we're going to find out so they had
a network of channels and I just walked
into one of them the roof is 15 feet
high there are subtitles going off to
the left and the right this is a
remarkable complex of bunkers underneath
duma which until march april was in
control of the rebels notably Jaysh
al-islam it's quite a work of
engineering something that's been done
by people who who really know how to
build things i entered it along a tunnel
which has been excavated from solid clay
and pebbles and stones which is big
enough to drive a vehicle down in this
section of the tunnel there are a lot of
semi burned documents left on the floor
clearly they try to destroy them before
they left and there are burnt-out
vehicles in here too all the walls are
burnt there must have been a big fire in
here at some point
sit down on the third level here and it
is it's much more dank there's a load of
discarded clothes on the floor of the
kitchen bathroom everything's filthy as
you can imagine and there's even fourth
level I can see down below this was a
entire subterranean life I guess
necessary when there was so much
shelling I've reached what appears to
have been a conference room at one end
there's a big display of a tank with
Jaysh al-islam colors in front of the
umayyad mosque right in the centre of
Damascus a place they never reached of
course a place they wanted to get to and
very detailed maps based on aerial
photos and there's one here which is
mounted in a wooden frame and every
building on it is numbered they were
organized for more than five years there
was a parallel state if you like here in
eastern Goethe on the outside on the
outskirts of Damascus
now the rebels who were headquartered
here who thought they were going to win
the war have been destroyed have been
have been beaten
so now there are big questions about
Syria's future what kind of country is
is going to be what a price has been
paid after all the years of destruction
and bloodletting around half a million
people dead half the pre-war population
1112 million people have lost their
homes or they've been driven abroad as
refugees it's going to take them a
generation at least to recover the war
of course still isn't over
